title: How to Take a Professional Quality Portrait of Your Pet

steps.headline: Consider having an assistant or handler for the animal.
steps.description: It is almost impossible to work with the animal, get the pose you want, get back to the camera and get the shot...after checking the focus.

steps.headline: Use natural light.
steps.description: If you can't go outside, then try using a well lit room, or a patio door with a lot of light coming in from the outside. It is less hot than strobe lights and is less location-dependent.

steps.headline: Focus on the eyes.
steps.description: If the rest of the image is blurry, but the eyes are sharp, this makes the rest of the image seem acceptable to the viewer's eyes. This can be important in both pet and people photography.

steps.headline: Shoot at your pet's eye level.
steps.description: It makes for a more natural looking picture. Your pet will also be more comfortable if you aren't looming over them when taking the photo.

steps.headline: Show your pet's personality and character.
steps.description: If your cat is lazy, get her by the window resting in the light. If he is active, show him in mid leap.

steps.headline: Shoot close up.
steps.description: Don't have your scene show a dog in it - then you don't know what the shot is. Get close up and zoom in.

steps.headline: Have you ever tried to take a picture of your pet, but they do not make eye contact with the camera?
steps.description: Whistle or snap and they will be surprised and concentrate on the movement or noise.

steps.headline: For a relaxed, formal portrait, schedule your session when the animal is somewhat sleepy or has just woke up.
steps.description: If you want a more lively shot, shoot them when they are more alert. Pets tend to be alert near dinnertime and more relaxed after their meal.

steps.headline: Be patient.
steps.description: It takes a lot of trial and error to get that winning shot.

steps.headline: Experiment with angles and positions.
steps.description: Like people, some animals are photogenic and some aren't. Try adjusting the viewpoint, or go for a silhouette. After all, the reaches of photography are limitless!

text: Consider having an assistant or handler for the animal. It is almost impossible to work with the animal, get the pose you want, get back to the camera and get the shot...after checking the focus. Use natural light. If you can't go outside, then try using a well lit room, or a patio door with a lot of light coming in from the outside. It is less hot than strobe lights and is less location-dependent. Focus on the eyes. If the rest of the image is blurry, but the eyes are sharp, this makes the rest of the image seem acceptable to the viewer's eyes. This can be important in both pet and people photography. Shoot at your pet's eye level. It makes for a more natural looking picture. Your pet will also be more comfortable if you aren't looming over them when taking the photo. Show your pet's personality and character. If your cat is lazy, get her by the window resting in the light. If he is active, show him in mid leap. Shoot close up. Don't have your scene show a dog in it - then you don't know what the shot is. Get close up and zoom in. Have you ever tried to take a picture of your pet, but they do not make eye contact with the camera? Whistle or snap and they will be surprised and concentrate on the movement or noise. For a relaxed, formal portrait, schedule your session when the animal is somewhat sleepy or has just woke up. If you want a more lively shot, shoot them when they are more alert. Pets tend to be alert near dinnertime and more relaxed after their meal. Be patient. It takes a lot of trial and error to get that winning shot. Experiment with angles and positions. Like people, some animals are photogenic and some aren't. Try adjusting the viewpoint, or go for a silhouette. After all, the reaches of photography are limitless!
